case_name: H.H. the Maharana Sahib Shri Bhagwat Singh Bahadur v. State of Rajasthan

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 528 of 1963 is an appeal from the judgment and order dated March 28, 1962 of the Rajasthan High Court in D.B. Civil Writ Petition No. 164 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 528 of 1963. Appeal from the judgment and order dated March 28, 1962 of the Rajasthan High Court in D.B. Civil Writ Petition No. 164 of 1961.

facts.text: H.H. the Maharana Sahib Shri Bhagwat Singh Bahadur was recognised as the Ruler of Udaipur with effect from July 4, 1955 in succession to his father the late Maharana Bhupal Singh.

anchor.surface_text: By order of the President of India, H.H. the Maharana Sahib Shri Bhagwat Singh Bahadur hereinafter called the appellant--was recognised as the Ruler of Udaipur with effect from July 4, 1955 in succession to his father the late Maharana Bhupal Singh.

facts.text: A dispute arose between the appellant and his employees in the Motor Garage Department about the conditions of employment.

anchor.surface_text: A, dispute arose between the appellant and his employees in the Motor Garage Department about the companyditions of employment and representations were made by the latter to the Government of Rajasthan through the Motor Workers Mazdoor Union, Udaipur.

facts.text: Representations were made by the employees to the Government of Rajasthan through the Motor Workers Mazdoor Union, Udaipur.

anchor.surface_text: A, dispute arose between the appellant and his employees in the Motor Garage Department about the companyditions of employment and representations were made by the latter to the Government of Rajasthan through the Motor Workers Mazdoor Union, Udaipur.

facts.text: Government of the State of Rajasthan referred the dispute under s. 10 of the Industrial Disputes Act 14 of 1947 to the Industrial Tribunal, Rajasthan on December 18, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The Government of the State of Rajasthan, on December 18, 1957 referred under s. 10 of the Industrial Disputes Act  14 of 1947 , the following dispute to the Industrial Tribunal, Rajasthan

facts.text: The reference concerns whether the Maharana Sahib Bahadur of Udaipur is liable to pay to the staff working with him in the Palace Power House and Motor Garage, consequent to their retrenchment, the arrears of claims or the due salary, leave wages, overtime wages and weekly holidays as per schedule appended hereto and if so, to what extent.

anchor.surface_text: Whether the Maharana Sahib Bahadur of Udaipur is liable to pay to the staff working with him in the Palace Power House and Motor Garage, companysequent to their retrenchment, the arrears of claims or the due salary, leave wages, overtime wages and weekly holidays as per schedule appended here to and if so, to what extent.

facts.text: Two preliminary objections were raised before the Industrial Tribunal by the appellant against the maintainability of the reference.

anchor.surface_text: Two preliminary objections were raised before the Industrial Tribunal by the appellant against the maintainability of the reference That the reference to the Industrial Tribunal for adjudication of the dispute was number maintainable without the previous sanction of the Central Government to the making of the reference.

facts.text: First preliminary objection: the reference was not maintainable without previous sanction of the Central Government.

anchor.surface_text: That the reference to the Industrial Tribunal for adjudication of the dispute was number maintainable without the previous sanction of the Central Government to the making of the reference.

facts.text: Second preliminary objection: on the date of reference no Industrial Tribunal was constituted under s. 7A of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947 as amended by Act 36 of 1956, and on reconstitution the reference became incompetent.

anchor.surface_text: That on the date when the reference was made numberIndustrial Tribunal was companystituted under s. 7A of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, as amended by Act 36 of 1956, and on reconstitution of the Tribunal, the reference became incompetent.

facts.text: The Tribunal rejected both preliminary objections.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal rejected both the objections and a writ petition filed by the appellant challenging the validity of the order of the Tribunal was dismissed by the High Court of Rajasthan.

facts.text: A writ petition filed by the appellant challenging the validity of the order of the Tribunal was dismissed by the High Court of Rajasthan.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal rejected both the objections and a writ petition filed by the appellant challenging the validity of the order of the Tribunal was dismissed by the High Court of Rajasthan.

facts.text: The appellant appealed to this Court with certificate granted by the High Court of Rajasthan.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant has appealed to this Court, with certificate granted by the High Court of Rajasthan.

facts.text: Appellant contends that without sanction of the Union Government under s. 87B of the Code of Civil Procedure, the reference was incompetent.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant companytends in the first instance that without the sanction of the Union Government under s. 87B of the Code of Civil Procedure, the reference to the Industrial Tribunal was incompetent.

facts.text: Industrial Disputes Act applied to the territory of Rajasthan at the material time.

anchor.surface_text: The Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, therefore, applied at the material time to the territory of Rajasthan.

facts.text: Industrial Tribunal for Rajasthan constituted by notification dated June 2, 1953 under s. 7 of the Industrial Disputes Act.

anchor.surface_text: an Industrial Tribunal was thereafter companystituted by numberification dated June 2, 1953, under s. 7 of that Act.

facts.text: Industrial Disputes Act amended by Act 36 of 1956, deleting s.7 and enacting ss.7,7A,7B,7C.

anchor.surface_text: The Industrial Disputes Act was, however, amended by the Industrial Disputes  Amendment and Miscellaneous Provisions  Act  36 of 1956 , and s. 7 as originally enacted was deleted and in lieu thereof ss. 7, 7A. 7B and 7C were enacted.

facts.text: High Court of Rajasthan in Writ Petition No. 107 of 1958 held that reference to Tribunal constituted under s.7 before amendment was incompetent.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Rajasthan in Writ Petition No. 107 of 1958--Mundra Metal Works Private Ltd. v. The State of Rajasthan and two others--held that the reference made to the Tribunal which was companystituted under s. 7 of the Industrial Disputes Act before it was amended by Act 36 of 1956 was incompetent.

facts.text: State Government reconstituted the Tribunal under s.7A by notification dated April 16, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: The State Government then reconstituted the Tribunal under s. 7A of the Act by numberification dated April 16, 1959,

facts.text: Rajasthan Industrial Tribunal Constitution and Proceedings Validating Act, 1959 was enacted, reserved for President's consideration and received assent.

facts.text: By s.2(1) of Validating Act, the Tribunal constituted under s.7 by notification June 2, 1953 is deemed duly constituted under s.7A for period March 10, 1957 to April 15, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Two preliminary objections were raised before the Industrial Tribunal by the appellant against the maintainability of the reference That the reference to the Industrial Tribunal for adjudication of the dispute was number maintainable without the previous sanction of the Central Government to the making of the reference.

arguments.claim: On the date of reference, no Industrial Tribunal was constituted under s.7A of the Industrial Disputes Act as amended, and reconstitution made the reference incompetent without fresh reference.

anchor.surface_text: That on the date when the reference was made numberIndustrial Tribunal was companystituted under s. 7A of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, as amended by Act 36 of 1956, and on reconstitution of the Tribunal, the reference became incompetent.

arguments.court_reasoning: Rajasthan Industrial Tribunal Constitution and Proceedings Validating Act, 1959 deems the tribunal duly constituted under s.7A retrospectively and validates references and proceedings during the period.

arguments.claim: Rajasthan Industrial Tribunal Constitution and Proceedings Validating Act, 1959 validly deems tribunal constituted under s.7A retrospectively and validates reference/proceedings; within state competence under List III Item 22, prevails by Art.254(2).

anchor.surface_text: the Legislature has remedied the defects, if any, in the constitution of the Tribunal, by enacting the Rajasthan Industrial Tribunal Constitution and Proceedings Validating Act, 1959, which was reserved for the consideration of the President of India and has received his assent.

arguments.claim: Tribunal's preliminary objections rejected; reference maintainable.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal rejected both the objections and a writ petition filed by the appellant challenging the validity of the order of the Tribunal was dismissed by the High Court of Rajasthan.

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court rightly negatived contentions; affirmed by Supreme Court.

holdings.text: Section 86 of the Code excludes the jurisdiction of the civil courts and must be strictly construed It does not debar the commencement of proceedings for adjudication of an industrial dispute for two reasons neither party to the proceeding is sued by the initiation of the proceeding, and the Tribunal is not a court.

anchor.surface_text: Section 86 of the Code excludes the jurisdiction of the civil courts and must be strictly construed It does not debar the commencement of proceedings for adjudication of an industrial dispute for two reasons neither party to the proceeding is sued by the initiation of the proceeding, and the Tribunal is not a court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: ID Act reference is not a suit in a civil court requiring consent under ss.86,87B CPC as proceedings do not commence by plaint, no party is sued, and tribunal is not a court; provision strictly construed.

holdings.text: In the absence of evidence directed to the question whether the appellant as Ruler of the Indian State of Udaipur was entitled by virtue of the covenant or agreement relied upon by him to the privilege of not being proceeded against in the Industrial Tribunal, we would not be justified in entertaining his plea.

anchor.surface_text: In the absence of evidence directed to the question whether the appellant as Ruler of the Indian State of Udaipur was entitled by virtue of the covenant or agreement relied upon by him to the privilege of not being proceeded against in the Industrial Tribunal, we would not be justified in entertaining his plea.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plea under Art.362 rejected procedurally as not raised in High Court, no evidence led on specific covenant guarantee of immunity from industrial adjudication.

holdings.text: We therefore decline to express any opinion on the questions whether by Art. 362 the appellant is privileged against a reference under the Industrial Disputes Act and also whether the courts have jurisdiction to adjudicate upon the plea set up by the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore decline to express any opinion on the questions whether by Art. 362 the appellant is privileged against a reference under the Industrial Disputes Act and also whether the courts have jurisdiction to adjudicate upon the plea set up by the appellant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Substantive questions on Art.362 and possible Art.363 bar not decided due to procedural defects.

holdings.text: It is clear from the validating provisions that the Tribunal originally constituted under s. 7 of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, before it was amended by Act 36 Of 1956 is to be deemed to have been duly constituted under s.7A, and the reference made on December 18, 1957 is to be deemed to have been made as if the Tribunal were constituted under s. 7A of the amended Act.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Rajasthan Validating Act retrospectively deems tribunal constituted under s.7A and validates references/proceedings despite prior defects.

holdings.text: The Validating Act is, because of Item 22, List III of the Seventh Schedule to the Constitution, within the competence of the State Legislature, and it was reserved for the consideration of the President and has received his assent. It must by virtue of Art. 254(2) prevail in the State of Rajasthan.

anchor.surface_text: The Validating Act is, because of Item 22, List III of the Seventh Schedule to the Constitution, within the competence of the State Legislature, and it was reserved for the consideration of the President and has received his assent. It must by virtue of Art. 254(2) prevail in the State of Rajasthan.

holdings.reasoning_summary: State validating legislation competent under concurrent list, prevails post-presidential assent per Art.254(2).

holdings.text: The second contention was, in our judgment, rightly negatived by the High Court.
holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court correctly rejected objection on tribunal constitution, affirmed post-validation.

holdings.text: The contentions raised in this appeal must therefore fail.
holdings.reasoning_summary: All preliminary objections rejected; reference maintainable.

precedents.citation: Sudhansu Shekhar Singh Deo v. State of Orissa 1

anchor.surface_text: This Court in Sudhansu Shekhar Singh Deo v. State of Orissa 1 observed at p. 786 If, despite the recommendation that due regard shall be had to the guarantee or assurance given under the companyenant or agreement, the Parliament or the Legislature of a State makes laws inconsis  1  1961 1 S.C.R.779,786.

precedents.case_name: Sudhansu Shekhar Singh Deo v. State of Orissa
precedents.cited_proposition: If, despite the recommendation that due regard shall be had to the guarantee or assurance given under the companyenant or agreement, the Parliament or the Legislature of a State makes laws inconsistent with the personal rights, privileges and dignities of the Ruler of an Indian State, the exercise of the legislative authority cannot, relying upon the agreement or companyenant, be questioned in any companyrt, as provided by Art. 363.
precedents.cited_holding: the exercise of the legislative authority cannot, relying upon the agreement or companyenant, be questioned in any companyrt, and that is so expressly provided by Art. 363 of the Constitution.
